# Draft:Howard Caldwell (admiral)

Howard Caldwell
0-61115
Early life
Caldwell was born 3 October 1905
Naval Academy and college football
]]
Navy Midshipmen football team, 1926 Armyâ€“Navy Game
Caldwell graduated as a member of the Class of 1927.
Later life and death
Caldwell died on 22 March, 1985.
Navy career
Caldwell was the commanding officer of an air group that embarked from the USS Saratoga and attacked JApanese warships in the Bombing of Rabaul on 5 November 1943. During the attack, he piloted a Torpedo bomber and, with assistance from a fighter pilot, destroyed between one and three enemy aircrafts. His plane received heavy damage, baring 116 bullet holes, and one member of its crew was killed while another was wounded. Nevertheless, Caldwell managed to return his plane to the USS Saratoga and land. He was awarded the Navy Cross for this.
From 30 September 1965 to 31 October 1967, Caldwell (while the United States was engaged in the Vietnam War) Caldwell served as the Commander Fleet Air at Naval Air Station Jacksonville. He was task group commander of major training exercises, and also commanded forces that were part of the joint NATO exercise LASHOUT.
Caldwell retired as a Rear Admiral.
Military awards
*Navy Cross for World War II
*Distinguished Flying Cross for World War II
*Legion of Merit for the Vietnam War (awarded February 1968)
